Description: Leap Day Agreement: North Korea agrees to a moratorium on long-range missile launches, nuclear tests, and uranium enrichment for 240,000 tons of US food aid.
Special Representative for North Korea Policy Glyn Davies meets North Korean First Vice Foreign Minister Kim Kye-gwan in Beijing to discuss a nuclear deal.
Ambassadors Glyn Davies and Stephen Bosworth talk with North Korean counterparts in Geneva regarding steps to resume the six-party process.
US Special Representative for North Korea Policy Stephen Bosworth and Kim Kye-gwan have talks in New York designed to explore the willingness of North Korea to take steps toward denuclearization.

US Special Representative to North Korea Stephen Bosworth travels to Pyongyang for exploratory talks with First Vice Foreign Minister Kang Sok-ju, Vice Foreign Minister Kim Kye-gwan, and others. The purpose of the meeting is to facilitate the resumption of the Six-Party Talks.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Lee Myung-bak, Taro Aso, Dmitry Medvedev
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: Six Party Talks in Beijing end in failure after North Korea refuses to sign onto a Chinese draft of a verification protocol.
Chris Hill visits Pyongyang with a US delegation that includes Sung Kim to discuss the Six Party Talks verification protocol.
Sung Kim meets with DPRK officials in New York to discuss verification revisions to the US draft verification protocol.
Sung Kim and Ri Gun, head of the North Korean Foreign Ministry's American affairs bureau meet in Beijing but fail to narrow differences on verification.
Sung Kim and Ri Gun, head of the North Korean Foreign Ministry's American affairs bureau meet in Beijing but fail to narrow differences on verification.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Lee Myung-bak, Yasuo Fukuda, Dmitry Medvedev
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: Foreign Ministers of the Six Party Talks countries have an informal meeting in Singapore on the sidelines of the ASEAN security forum.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Lee Myung-bak, Yasuo Fukuda, Dmitry Medvedev
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: Six party talks are held in Beijing after a 9-month break where they discuss the verification protocol.

Chris Hill and Sung Kim persuade North Korea to shut down the reactor at Yongbyon and blow up the reactor's cooling tower to demonstrate their commitment to denuclearization. The cooling tower is demolished by North Korea on June 27, 2008.
Chris Hill meets Kim Kye-gwan in Beijing where they discuss North Korea's nuclear declaration and a submission timeline.

North Korea gives Sung Kim 18,822 pages of documents related to its plutonium program in Pyongyang. The US delegation also holds discussions with DPRK interlocutors from the Foreign Ministry and the General Department of Atomic Energy on all aspects of their declaration.
Sung Kim leads a US interagency delegation to North Korea to discuss the tentative agreement reached between Chris Hill and Kim Kye-gwan on April 8.
Chris Hill meets Kim Kye-gwan in Singapore to discuss the Six-Party process. They reach a compromise on a tentative agreement.
Chris Hill holds in depth discussions on many aspects of the nuclear issue with his North Korean counterpart, Kim Kye-gwan, in Geneva.
DPRK Vice Foreign Minister Kim Kye-gwan flies to Beijing to meet with US Assistant Secretary of State Christopher Hill. In the unannounced talks they discuss the six party talks and declaration.
Director of the US State Department's Office of Korea Affairs, Sung Kim, visits Pyongyang to discuss how to make progress on the six-party talks process.
Chris Hill has a full tour of disablement activities at Yongbyon and has further talks with Kim Kye-gwan in Pyongyang about the December 31 package and next steps.
Sung Kim and a team of experts continue discussions on the disabling of Yongbyon nuclear facilities in North Korea.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Yasuo Fukuda, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: The "Second-Phase Actions for the Implementation of the September 2005 Joint Statement" is adopted in which North Korea agrees to declare its entire nuclear program by December 31, 2007 and to disable its main nuclear facilities according to the February 13 agreement. The US agrees to remove North Korea's "state sponsor of terrorism" designation. All parties reaffirm their commitment to deliver the remaining 900,000 tons of heavy fuel oil to North Korea.
Sung Kim and a team of experts discuss the disabling of Yongbyon nuclear facilities in North Korea.
In talks with Chris Hill in Geneva, North Korea says they will provide a full declaration of all of their nuclear programs and will disable the programs by the end of 2007.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Shinzo Abe, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: The 6th round of Six-Party Talks continue. Kim Kye-gwan says his country will declare all its nuclear programs without omitting anything, but the parties cannot agree on a hard deadline for disarming nuclear weapons.

Chris Hill visits Pyongyang at the invitation of the DPRK and meets with Foreign Minister Park Ui-chun. The meeting is part of ongoing consultations with the six parties on implementation of the Initial Actions agreement.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Shinzo Abe, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: At the 6th round of Six Party Talks in Beijing the parties report on the first meetings of the five working group. North Korea refuses to engage in further talks until Banco Delta Asia accounts are unfrozen.

Meeting of US-DPRK Bilateral Working Group: Ambassador Chris Hill leads comprehensive discussions in New York on implementing the shutdown of the Yongbyon reactor and the reintroduction of IAEA personnel to monitor and verify those procedures.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Shinzo Abe, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: An agreement is reached at the 5th round of Six Party Talks in Beijing called "Initial Actions for the Implementation of the Joint Statement". North Korea agrees to shut down and seal nuclear facilities at Yongbyon within 60 days and to allow IAEA monitoring and verification in exchange for 50,000 tons of heavy fuel oil.
Chris Hill meets with Kim Kye-gwan in Berlin to discuss reviving six party talks.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Junichiro Koizumi, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: Second phase of 5th round of Six Party Talks. North Korea focuses almost exclusively on Banco Delta Asia designation, blocking progress.
Chris Hill and Kim Kye-gwan meet in Beijing for talks after North Korea conducts its first nuclear weapons test on October 9, 2006.
US and DPRK officials meet in New York to discuss the Banco Delta Asia action.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao
Description: Christopher Hill, Kim Kye-gwan, and Wu Dawei meet in Beijing to discuss reviving the stalled Six Party Talks process.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Junichiro Koizumi, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: The 5th round of Six Party Talks. North Korea focuses on Banco Delta Asia issue and little progress is made. The KEDO project is terminated later that month on November 29th.
Chris Hill and DPRK officials meet in New York for talks.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Junichiro Koizumi, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: At the 4th round of Six Party Talks the parties agree on a joint statement of principles to guide future negotiations.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Junichiro Koizumi, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: At the 4th round of Six Party Talks North Korea argues that dismantling nuclear weapons must be matched with assurances of regime security. The DPRK delegation also wants lifting of economic sanctions and normalization of relations with the US and Japan. The US delegation insists that dismantling must be verifiable and irreversible.
Chris Hill meets with Kim Kye-gwan. Pyongyang agrees to return to six-party talks.
North Korean ambassador to the United Nations Pak Gil Yon and US special envoy to the Six-Party Talks Joseph DeTrani meet in New York to discuss resuming six-party talks.
After a public appeal by North Korea, the US sends Ambassador Joseph R. DeTrani, the US special envoy to North Korea to the UN mission in New York to reiterate the US positions and assurances.
Joseph DeTrani meets DPRK representative in New York to urge a return to six-party talks without preconditions.
Joseph DeTrani meets DPRK representative in New York to urge a return to six-party talks without preconditions.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Junichiro Koizumi, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: UN General Assembly President Jean Ping makes a visit to Pyongyang to meet with DPRK Foreign Minister Paek Nam-sun and President of the Supreme People's Assembly Presidium Kim Yong-nam.
Colin Powell meets with NK counterpart Paek Nam Sun in Jakarta. Powell says a deal depends on North Korea declaring all their nuclear activities.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Junichiro Koizumi, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: The 3rd round of six-party talks are held and various comprehensive proposals are introduced by the US side. The DPRK side warns that North Korea will test a nuclear weapon unless its proposals are accepted.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Junichiro Koizumi, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: The second working-level meeting to prepare for six-party talks.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Junichiro Koizumi, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: United Nations Special Envoy Maurice Strong visits Pyongyang. North Korea says they will continue to develop their nuclear program.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Junichiro Koizumi, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: At the six-party talks working-group meeting in Beijing, North Korea says they will never accept US demands for complete dismantlement.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Junichiro Koizumi, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: The 2nd round of Six Party Talks in Beijing fail to make progress. Washington and Pyongyang disagree over the latter's desire to retain some nuclear capabilities for peaceful purposes.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao, Roh Moo-hyun, Junichiro Koizumi, Vladimir Putin
Parties Involved: US, DPRK, China, ROK, Japan, Russia
Description: At the 1st round of Six-Party Talks in Beijing, no major breakthroughs are achieved. North Korea calls for a step-by-step solution and explicitly denies for the first time that it has a uranium-enrichment program. The North Korean officials also threaten to test nuclear weapons.
US and DPRK representatives meet in New York to discuss a multilateral format for future high-level talks.

Leadership: George W. Bush, Kim Jong-il, Hu Jintao
Description: Three party talks in Beijing (US, NK and China). North Korea admits for the first time that they possess nuclear weapons but would be willing to get rid of all their nuclear programs if they get something considerable in return. On January 10, 2003 North Korea had announced its intent to withdraw from NPT.

Assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, James Kelly, visits North Korea where he confronts Pyongyang over their HEU program. On the second day, Pyongyang admits to having an HEU program. Kelly advocates finding a comprehensive settlement.
Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO) delegation visits Pyongyang to discuss spent fuel rod storage with North Koreans.
Jack Pritchard, US Representative to KEDO, attends a ceremony to celebrate the initial building of the foundation for the first light water reactor and to discuss the project with North Koreans.
US Secretary of State Colin Powell meets with North Korean Foreign Minister Paek Nam Sun in Brunei, on the sidelines of ASEAN Regional Forum.

Ambassador Jack Pritchard, Special Envoy for Negotiations with the DPRK, meets with North Korean Ambassador Pak Kil Yon at North Korea's Permanent Mission to the UN in New York where they discuss dates for potential upcoming meetings.
DPRK and US officials meet in New York to discuss resumption of talks with KEDO.

DPRK officials and KEDO delegation engage in talks about the light water reactor project. Charles Kartman meets with Kim Song Su the DPRK project director for the light water reactors. The Quality and Assurance and Warranties Protocol is also signed.
DPRK officials and KEDO delegation engage in talks about the light water reactor project.
DPRK officials and KEDO delegation engage in talks about the light water reactor project.
KEDO delegation visits Pyongyang to attend the groundbreaking ceremony for light water reactors.
DPRK officials and KEDO delegation engage in talks about the light water reactor project.
DPRK officials and KEDO members conduct negotiations on a quality assurance and warranties protocol for the light water reactors project.
US Special Envoy Jack Pritchard meets with North Korean representative to the UN Yi Hyong chol in New York to discuss details of bilateral talks.
DPRK officials and KEDO delegation engage in talks about the light water reactor project in Pyongyang. Earlier in the month Charles Kartman had been named the new executive director of KEDO.
DPRK officials and KEDO delegation engage in talks about the light water reactor project in Pyongyang.
KEDO experts and DPRK officials meet in New York to discuss technical issues and North Korea's nuclear regulatory environment.
Seventh round of missile talks in Pyongyang end without an agreement.
US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright visits Pyongyang and talks with Kim Jong-il on nuclear and missile issues.
KEDO executive director Desaix Anderson signs a protocol related to the training of North Korean workers for the LWR project with DPRK officials in Pyongyang.
Vice Marshal Jo Myong Rok visits Washington and meets with President Clinton. The two sides issue the US-DPRK Joint Communique in which they agree to work together on a range of issues.

Kim Kye-gwan and Charles Kartman meet in New York to discuss nuclear issues, NK missiles, and terrorism. The two sides issue a joint statement on terrorism in which "the two sides agreed that international terrorism poses an unacceptable threat to global security and peace, and that terrorism should be opposed in all its forms."
US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and DPRK Foreign Minister Paek Nam Sun meet in Bangkok during the ASEAN regional forum.

At the 5th round of missile talks in Kuala Lumpur between the US and North Korea the US rejects Pyongyang's demand for monetary compensation in exchange for stopping missile exports but says it is willing to move toward economic normalization in return for addressing US concerns.
KEDO and DPRK officials meet to discuss light water reactor project in North Korea.
Preparatory session for 5th round of US-DPRK missile talks held in Rome.
Delegations from the US and DPRK meet in Rome to discuss their respective concerns regarding the implementation of the Agreed Framework and other bilateral issues.
KEDO and DPRK officials discuss light water reactor project in Hyangsan, North Korea.

Ambassador Charles Kartman and DPRK Vice Foreign Minister Kim Kye-gwan meet in New York. They agree to schedule further talks on US concerns on the DPRK's missile program and talks on Agreed Framework implementation.
KEDO and DPRK officials discuss light water reactor project in Hyangsan, North Korea.
Ambassador Charles Kartman and Vice Foreign Minister Kim Kye-gwan meet in Berlin to exchange views. They agree to a high-level visit in the near future.
Ambassador Charles Kartman leads a delegation to Berlin to talk with DPRK Vice Foreign Minister Kim Kye-gwan and other officials.
KEDO and DPRK officials meet in New York to discuss technical issues and a memoradium of understanding on indemnification and environmental issues.
Ambassador Charles Kartman leads a delegation to Berlin to talk with DPRK Vice Foreign Minister Kim Kye-gwan and other officials.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Jiang Zemin, Kim Dae-jung
Description: Four-Party Talks in Geneva.
Charles Kartman meets North Korean Vice Foreign Minister Kim Kye-gwan in Beijing to discuss the recent Kumchang-ni inspection, implementation of the agreed framework, and upcoming Four-Party talks.
US special envoy William Perry leads a delegation to Pyongyang and meets with high-ranking DPRK officials.
Charles Kartman travels to Pyongyang to make final arrangements for the Kumchang-ri site inspections.
The US and DPRK hold further talks regarding the details of Kumchang-ri inspections on the sidelines of the Four-Party talks.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Jiang Zemin, Kim Dae-jung
Description: Four-Party Talks in Geneva.
KEDO experts and DPRK officials meet in New York to discuss technical issues and training of North Korean engineers.
US officials and nuclear experts travel to Pyongyang to make arrangements necessary for the Kumchang-ri site inspections.
A US delegation led by Assistant Secretary Robert Einhorn holds bilateral missiles talks with the DPRK side in Pyongyang.
IAEA and North Korea hold talks in Vienna over Pyongyang's denial of access to information needed to verify nuclear material.
After four rounds of talks, an agreement is reached to allow multiple site visits by a US team to the underground site at Kumchang-ri.
Bilateral talks on the suspected underground site at Kumchang-ri.
KEDO and DPRK officials discuss light water reactor project in Hyangsan, North Korea.
Kim Kye-gwan and Charles Kartman resume talks in Geneva about Kumchang-ri.
KEDO and DPRK officials discuss light water reactor project in Hyangsan, North Korea.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Jiang Zemin, Kim Dae-jung
Description: Four-Party Talks in Geneva.
Kim Kye-gwan and Charles Kartman talk in Geneva about allowing inspections at Kumchang-ri.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Jiang Zemin, Kim Dae-jung
Description: Working-level meeting to discuss arrangements for the fourth plenary session of the four-party talks.
Kim Kye-gwan and Charles Kartman resume negotiations in New York on Kumchang-ri. The two sides recognize that progress was made and agree to meet again.
Bilateral talks in New York to discuss suspected underground facility at Kumchang-ri.

US Special Envoy for the Korean Peace Talks Charles Kartman leads a delegation to Pyongyang to discuss underground construction at Kumchang-ri. Disagreements are reported over whether the underground facilities are part of a nuclear program.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Jiang Zemin, Kim Dae-jung
Description: Third plenary session of the Four-party Talks in Geneva.
IAEA and DPRK officials hold talks in Pyongyang over North Korea's denial of access to information needed to verify nuclear material.

Third round of bilateral missile talks in New York. The US delegation is led by Robert Einhorn, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Political-Military Affairs. The North Korean delegation is led by Han Chang On, Director of the Department of US Affairs of the DPRK Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Delegations led by Charles Kartman and DPRK vice foreign minister Kim Kye-gwan meet in New York.”

Delegations led by Charles Kartman and DPRK vice foreign minister Kim Kye-gwan meet in New York. Pyongyang agrees to continue meetings on underground construction and missile programs and canning of remaining spent fuel rods starting in mid-September.
US deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asia and Pacific affairs Charles Kartman and North Korea's deputy ambassador to the UN Lee Kun meet.
KEDO and North Korean officials meet to discuss delivery of heavy fuel oil and other technical issues.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Jiang Zemin, Kim Dae-jung
Description: Second plenary session of the Four-party Talks in Geneva. There is disagreement over whether to include removal of US forces from the peninsula on the agenda.
DPRK and US delegations led by Kim Kye-gwan and Charles Kartman respectively meet in Berlin for talks leading up to the Four-party talks.
KEDO experts and DPRK officials meet in Pyongyang to discuss technical issues.
KEDO and DPRK officials hold working-level talks to discuss technical issues for light water reactor project.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Jiang Zemin, Kim Young-sam
Description: Four-Party Talks in Geneva.
The US and North Korea have bilateral talks in Washington on a broad range of issues including the agreed framework, the four-party talks, the issue of food aid.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Jiang Zemin, Kim Young-sam
Description: Third preliminary talks on the Four-party Talks in New York.
KEDO executive director Desaix Anderson and DPRK officials meet in Pyongyang to discuss LWR project.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Jiang Zemin, Kim Young-sam
Description: Second preliminary talks on the Four-party Talks in New York.

During bilateral talks in New York the US informs North Korea that before unfreezing assets they plan to conduct a survey of the number and size of outstanding financial claims by US citizens against the DPRK.
Kim Kye-gwan and Charles Kartman talk in Beijing about high ranking North Korean defector Ambassador Chang Sung Kil and proposed four party talks.
Stephen Bosworth executive director of KEDO attends groundbreaking ceremony for LWR in North Korea with other KEDO and DPRK officials.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Kim Young-sam
Description: US-ROK-DPRK talks at Columbia University to discuss 4-party talks (Kim Kye-gwan, Song Yong shik, Charles Kartman).
KEDO liason office opened in North Korea.
The US and North Korea have bilateral talks in New York on a broad range of issues including the agreed framework, the four-party talks, the issue of food aid.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Jiang Zemin, Kim Young-sam
Description: First trilateral deputy-ministerial consultation on the Four-party Talks in New York.
KEDO and DPRK officials hold working-level talks to discuss technical issues for light water reactor project.
In the 2nd round of missile talks between the US and North Korea no agreement is reached.
KEDO and DPRK officials discuss construction process for the light water reactors in North Korea.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Kim Young-sam
Description: US-ROK-DPRK talks. The meeting was attended by Charles Kartman, Sung Young shik, and Kim Kye-gwan.
KEDO and DPRK officials discuss construction process for the light water reactors in Pyongyang.
KEDO and DPRK officials meet in New York to discuss indemnity protocol.
US-DPRK hold working-level talks in New York to explore issues involving the Four-Party peace proposal.

Leadership: Bill Clinton, Kim Jong-il, Kim Young-sam
Description: US-ROK-DPRK talks in New York.
KEDO executive director Stephen Bosworth and DPRK ambassador Ho Jong meet and sign two protocols for light water reactor project.
IAEA and DPRK officials meet to discuss safeguards agreement.
Director of the State Department's Office of Korean Affairs Mark Minton and Director of American Affairs in the North Korean Foreign Ministry Yi Hyong Chol hold working-level talks in New York.
KEDO and DPRK officials hold working-level talks in New York.
The IAEA and North Korea have negotiations in Vienna over the safeguards agreement and inspections.
KEDO and DPRK officials hold working-level talks to discuss technical issues and additional protocols for light water reactor project.
KEDO and DPRK officials hold working-level talks to discuss technical issues and additional protocols for light water reactor project.
KEDO and DPRK officials sign two technical protocols which were initiated at the end of negotiations on June 14.
KEDO and DPRK officials hold negotiations on two technical protocols which are signed at the end of negotiations process on July 11.
US-DPRK meet in Berlin for the first round of talks on missiles and non-proliferation.
KEDO and DPRK officials hold working-level talks to discuss technical issues for light water reactor project.
Stephen Bosworth KEDO executive director and DPRK officials meet to discuss light water reactor project.

Bilateral talks between North Korean ambassador-at-large Ho Jung and Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and Pacific, Thomas Hubbard, in New York. The light-water reactor agreement between KEDO and North Korea is signed on December 15.
KEDO and DPRK officials continue negotiations in New York on light water reactor supply agreement. The agreement is signed on December 15.
Stephen Bosworth KEDO executive director and DPRK ambassador Ho Jong conduct negotiations in New York on light water reactor supply agreement.
KEDO and DPRK officials hold working-level talks to discuss technical issues.
US and DPRK officials meet in Pyongyang to discuss opening of future liasion offices.
An IAEA team visits North Korea to negotiate expanding monitoring activities.
The Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization (KEDO) conducts talks with DPRK officials on supply of light-water reactors.
KEDO and DPRK officials hold working-level talks to discuss technical issues.
US and DPRK officials discuss spent fuel storage and waste management.
US and DPRK officials negotiate and reach agreement on the delivery of heavy fuel oil shipments and verification measures.
After three weeks of negotiations in Kuala Lumpur, the US and DPRK agree on the details of the provision of light water reactors.
During a meeting in Kuala Lumpur the US and DPRK officials negotiate and come to an agreement on South Korea's role in KEDO.
US-DPRK meet in Berlin to discuss the 1994 Agreed Framework.
US-DPRK meet in Berlin to discuss the 1994 Agreed Framework.
US-DPRK meet in Berlin to discuss the 1994 Agreed Framework and light water reactors.
US-DPRK meet in Berlin to discuss delivery of light water reactors.
Officials from North Korea and the IAEA continue consultations on the implementation and verification of the nuclear freeze agreement.
US and DPRK officials meet in Pyongyang to talk about spent fuel.

Discussions on the planned exchange of liaison offices between US and DPRK officials in Washington DC. A team of North Koreans visits Washington later in April 1995 to survey sites for future liasion office.
US and DPRK delegations hold talks in Beijing on the supply of light-water reactor power plants to replace the DPRK's graphite-moderated reactors and related facilities.

IAEA experts visit North Korea for talks on verification and monitoring of North Korea's nuclear reactors and related facilities. IAEA and North Korean officials also discuss Agreed Framework implementation in Vienna.
US experts visit North Korea to discuss spent fuel storage and waste management.

US and DPRK delegations hold talks in Geneva to negotiate an overall resolution of the nuclear issue. Due to deadlock, the talks are suspended September 29 to October 5. The Agreed Framework is adopted on October 21.
The US and DPRK hold expert-level discussions in Pyongyang (ending 9/14) and Berlin (ending 9/15) in accordance with the agreed statement of the third round of US-DPRK high-level talks.
The US and DPRK continue the 3rd round of high-level talks in Geneva and sign an agreed statement for denuclearization.
The US and DPRK meet in New York to reset the date and arrange details for the third round of high-level talks.
The US and DPRK begin talks in Geneva but they are postponed only a few hours upon news of the death of Kim Il sung.
The US and DPRK meet in New York to discuss logistical arrangements for the coming third round of high-level talks.

Former president Jimmy Carter visits North Korea at the invitation of Kim Il-sung. While in North Korea, Carter communicates a proposal to the Clinton administration in order to resume talks between the US and DPRK on IAEA inspections and North Korea's nuclear program. North Korea also agrees to a joint effort to recover the remains of US soldiers killed in the Korean War and plans for an inter-Korean summit.

IAEA and DPRK hold meeting in Pyongyang on fuel monitoring. On May 27, Hans Blix sends letter to UN Secretary-General stating that the talks have failed. North Korea's discharges of spent fuel have made it difficult to measure the use of nuclear material in its 5MW reactor.
The US and North Korea hold working-level talks in New York.
The US and North Korea hold working-level talks in New York. Shortly after talks North Korea gives notice to the IAEA that it has unloaded nuclear spent fuel rods from the Yongbyon reactor.
The US and North Korea hold working-level talks in New York. The two sides discuss IAEA inspections and the suspension of US-ROK military exercises.
The US and North Korea hold working-level talks in New York on IAEA inspections.
IAEA and DPRK agree on comprehensive list of safeguards measures to ensure that no nuclear material has been diverted from North Korea's nuclear facilities.
IAEA and DPRK officials hold a second round of working-level talks in Vienna on nuclear safeguards and inspections.
Talks between IAEA and DPRK in Vienna on nuclear safeguards.
Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia and the Pacific Tom Hubbard meets with North Korean Ambassador Ho Jong at the UN headquarters in New York.
US and DPRK political counselors meet in Beijing for discussions on political and nuclear issues.
Discussion between IAEA and DPRK in North Korea regarding nuclear safeguards implementation.
Working-level talks between DPRK and US in New York.

After a series of high-level meetings in Geneva between US and DPRK delegations led by US Assistant Secretary of State Robert Gallucci and Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Kang Sok Chu, respectively, the two sides agree on a plan to replace North Korean reactors with light water reactors.

US-DPRK high-level meetings at the UN mission in New York end with a joint statement agreeing on security assurances, a nuclear-free peninsula, the peaceful reunification of Korea, and the DPRK suspending withdrawal from NPT.
A working-level meeting is held in Beijing between the North Korean and the American political counselors.

A working-level meeting is held in Beijing between the North Korean and the American political counselors. North Korea had announced its intent to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty on March 12, 1993.
Further discussions between IAEA and DPRK on original nuclear material declaration. North Korea refuses special inspections.
Discussions in Pyongyang between IAEA and DPRK on discrepancies in nuclear material declaration.
High-level consultations between DPRK and IAEA on discrepancies in North Korea's initial declaration of nuclear material given to IAEA in May 1992.
North Korea and IAEA sign a nuclear safeguards agreement allowing inspections to begin in June 1992.
North Korea's Kim Yong Sun and Undersecretary of State Arnold L. Kanter meet in New York.
US-DPRK diplomatic talks held in Beijing.
In Beijing, US and DPRK officials discuss bilateral relations, inter-Korean relations, and the return of remains of US soldiers who fought in the Korean War.

US and North Korean officials discuss various issues in Beijing. The US requests that DPRK sign an IAEA safeguards agreement and North Korea requests the cancellation of US-ROK military exercises and withdrawal of US troops from the peninsula.
